All comments from @marmbrus were addressed, thanks for all the suggestions! Hope this can be a good foundation for future contributions :)

Visibility issue addressed. I think this is ready to be merged now. And please merge this PR _before_ #208, since that one affects lots of files and may cause potential conflicts. After this PR is merged, I'll merge master to #208, which would be easier to handle.
@mateiz I fixed that, I checked if DAGScheduler is null in runJob of SparkContext

Thanks, this looks good to me. In the long term, I think we were thinking of making spark-shell be a small shim around calling spark-app. In order to see that happen eventually, we will need their APIs to match precisely right now so we can muck with the implementation later.

Since Spark 1.0 pull request freeze is planned for April 1, I'm planning to go ahead and merge this now and iterate if necessary to make the arguments equivalent with those in #86 before the release.
Hey @srowen - I'm guessing that maven hostname delegates to a mirror/CDN network and maybe some of them support HTTPS and others don't. Seems fine to just fallback to HTTP in that case.

All automated tests passed.
Refer to this link for build results: https://amplab.cs.berkeley.edu/jenkins/job/SparkPullRequestBuilder/13368/
@haosdent could you add this to the SBT build as well? Look at how the other external projects work (e.g. twitter, mqtt, etc)

I looked at this a bit more closely. I'm definitely +1 on having some utility functions like this for writing to HBase.

It seems a bit brittle to me that we expect people to go through a textual representation of the records in order to save to HBase. I think a nicer way to do this would be to go through a SchemaRDD (which is a new feature recently merged into Spark) or even a Scala case class or Scala tuples. And then have an automatic conversion into HBase types based on the runtime type of the RDD. And you'd just need to give a mapping of the attribute names to the hbase column names (/cc @marmbrus).

This approach here seems a little bit more ad-hoc and like something we may not want to support for a long time going forward. So it might make sense to slot this for Spark 1.1 and re-work it to have more integrated support for schemas.
Okay I merged this into master. Feel free to bump #208 now.
will make sure the bash matches #86 by tomorrow am.

Jenkins, this is okay to test.

New NOTICE looks good. I'm going to merge this. I made a comment on what I meant for the squared distance part (I only wanted a reference on the threshold for numerical error, not the formula itself), but we can add some justification for that later if needed.

> I think a nicer way to do this would be to go through a SchemaRDD (which is a new feature recently merged into Spark) or even a Scala case class or Scala tuples.

@pwendell Thanks for your advice. Let me update it.
@mateiz Thanks! I will put a note about the numerical error later.
